titleStmt.author: Anon., 1765-1830 (Dramas of the Revolutionary and Early American Period)

front.head: TO THE EDITOR.
front.p: He that is always wise is no Blockhead; nor does it follow, that he who is not always wise is a Blockhead. — A Blockhead will scarely be claimed by any body in the universe — consequently you will find no one to own the heads I have described; of course you can be in no danger of a claimant, who will call you to an account for meddling with his head. — Yet Blockheads sometimes govern, and are governed, though not all times in their proper persons — a Deputy does the business best who is no Blockhead, and it please you if he does his own business under a Blockhead's nomination. — Contractors are no Blockheads, though Contractees often are. — It is strange there should be such a difference between Buyer and Buyee. — Who is in the wrong? No matter who — he is a Blockhead that owns it. Ergo, A wise man may be a Blockhead if he enters his claim to any of the heads in this petit piece.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: A Temple dedicated to the Goddess of Peace.
Peace in the form of a matron, ears of corn in one hand, crowned with roses, and a caduceus in the other hand.
Enter AMITA and Followers, With baskets of flowers and fruits, to make their offerings to the Goddess of Peace.

sp.speaker: AMITA.
sp.p:
Hail ! gentle Goddess! source of human love! — protectress of the spring renewing fields, and bounteous fruits — Accept these offerings of our earliest
produce — May each returning year renew our grateful praise, and keep the peaceful scene in view.

sp.speaker: AMITA, and Chorus.
sp.l: With each revolving year we bring,
Our chearful produce of the Spring
To thee. Oh! gentle Goddess, hear!
These Off'rings may we ever bear.
Our fields with plent'ous fruits abound,
Our golden harvests view around;
The offsprings of a bounteous peace;
Oh! may these offsprings never cease.
May war's rude hand for ever spare,
To stop these pledges of our care.
(Without thy aid we sue in vain)
May peace and plenty ever reign.

sp.speaker: AMITA.
sp.stage: (Thunder and lightening, the Temple of Peace vanishes in a dark cloud.)
sp.p: What blessings does not peace bestow? the gentle Goddess claims our utmost praise.
This dismal storm some mischief doth portend! Oh, heaven! avert the evil — dispel the gloomy cloud that hangs so heavy o'er our heads.

sp.speaker: PRODIGIATOR.
sp.p:
Mirth shall fly, nor more attend ye — commerce shall cease, and envious war extend it's baneful power — discord shall reign and rule this hapless land — friendship shall fly — plenty shall be no more —
all the delights of peace shall vanish — the awful time is come when wretched mortals, weltering in blood, shall add sad encrease to the flowing flood — conquering grief shall rob the widows and the orphans of their tears, and hollow caverns of despair burst forth in dismal shrieks that rend the ambient air.

sp.speaker: AMITA.
sp.p: Dread horror! can I forbear the mournful sigh, when dire distress bears such a powerful sway? — Anguish is full — my blood is chill'd — words are too feeble to express my grief — the passions combat which shall first break forth, whilst each maintain an equal claim, and leave no powers to express my anguish.

sp.speaker: PRODIGIATOR.
sp.l: Bleeding empires in distress,
Sue to tyrants for redress;
Hapless sons! that pant for breath,
Seek to find an end in death.
Freedom's sons, by fetters ty'd,
Curb'd in all their boasted pride,
Shall to distant shores proclaim,
Freemen will be free again.
Twice ten thousand torments bear,
E'er they pass the circling year;
May Halcyon days return once more,
And glad for aye this hapless shore.
Forth thy sleeping mansion rise,
And open thy unwilling eyes;
Return bless'd Peace, thy empire keep,
And haste to lull rude Mars to sleep.

sp.speaker: AMITA.
sp.p: Friendship, child of Heaven! — how are all thy ties destroyed when gratitude is fled!

sp.speaker: PRODIGIATOR.
sp.p: Who feels not for Amita's bosom, feels not for distress — Time shall renew what discord has destroyed, and happiness descend again.

sp.speaker: AMITA.
sp.l: Shall gladness quit the human heart?
Shall sorrow all her griefs impart?
Shall commerce fly? — Ah, hapless shore!
And mirth and freedom be no more?
Shall martial gluttony destroy
The mother's and the infant's joy?
Till then, alas! I sue in vain,
With tears I view the slaughter'd plain.

sp.speaker: LIBERTA.
sp.p: My dear Amita , why so pensive? — Fame is on the wing, and calls forth Freedom — In every countenance doth joy appear, big with events more glad'ning to the heart than all the soft delights of rural sports; yet you alone seem destin'd to distress.

sp.speaker: AMITA.
sp.p:
Distress shall reign triumphant o'er the realms of peace, and wretched war bring famine on this land — Oh, then, alas! shall poor expiring victims pant to quit their native land, in hope to meet with peace in death. — Alas! why heaves my
bosom thus? till now I never felt the power of love; freedom had taken possession of my heart, but fancy's wings have borne the lover to my mind, and social love's the idol of my heart.

sp.speaker: LIBERTA.
sp.p: Go! imitate the turtle dove — cherish the fond idea, but I'll be ever free — No proud insulting swain shall e'er beguile my heart — No, no, I'll ne'er sustain the loss of liberty.
sp.l: Dear liberty possess my breast,
Nor let the pleasing phantom rest,
Lest some sad fate produce a tear,
And make Liberta sink with fear.
In vain shall mischief take a part,
And prove the partner of my heart;
No jealous thought my breast possess,
No wanton swain I'll e'er caress.
But you, who trust to fortune's chance,
And catch the eye, and court the glance;
To those I yield the fickle glee,
But bless me still with Liberty.

sp.speaker: AMITA.
sp.p: Oh! Liberta ! must the peaceful scene be changed for discord and distress? — Is there no medium can be found to save a sinking state? — The mournful cloud moves on with hasty strides, and sprinkling showers give notice of approach — Unable longer to contain the dire contents, it bursts with fury, and proclaims the event; yet shall the poor shepherd brave the powerful storm, and bid defiance in expiring moments.

sp.speaker: LIBERTA.
sp.p:
I must this moment hence — The signal's given, and all repair — the standard's
fix'd — reas'nings in vain — The scene begins, and merriment's no more — Freedom forgets her mother's care — Love flies before our banners — Discord appears and hunts her from her rest — No cause but freedom fills the human heart — Who does not join's a traitor to mankind.

sp.speaker: AMITA.
sp.p: When love is fled society's no more, her ties are broke, and friendship's at a stand.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: A Barber's Shop in New York.
The shop is full of customers, wigs of different sorts on blocks, with masks painted. Over the door OLD SHAVER.

sp.speaker: SHAVER
sp.p: Old wigs, gentlemen! short wigs! bobbs! grizzles! tyes, and no tyes! Pick and chase, the price is fix'd. — This is a simple head of hair, not indebted to nature for a curl; the wearer was suspected of less courage than he possessed; he was provident in his principles, and sought for an independance.
This head had a great deal of good-nature, and wore it upon all occasions; but at last, influenced by the habit of the times, resolved on a change.
This wig cover'd the head of a lawyer — the tyes nearly gone; his principles induced him to turn his back on his best friends.

sp.speaker: OLD WIG.
sp.p: I will have a tye.

sp.speaker: YOUNG WIG.
sp.p: So will I.

sp.speaker: SHAVER.
sp.p:
Gentlemen, tyes are quite out of fashion — I have but one left, and that's so worn by time
(shews the wig)
that the tyes
(holds the tyes up)
are grown quite slender.

sp.speaker: OLD WIG.
sp.p: So much the better.

sp.speaker: YOUNG WIG.
sp.p: And so say I.

sp.speaker: OLD WIG.
sp.p: I like not strong ties.

sp.speaker: YOUNG WIG.
sp.p: Nor I:

sp.speaker: SHAVER.
sp.p:
Gentlemen, I have but one — there 'tis
(holds out the wig)
— settle the business between yourselves.

div.stage: Old and Young Wig lay hold of the tye.
DIALOGUE between YOUNG WIG, OLD WIG, and SHAVER.

sp.speaker: O. and Y.
sp.l: The wig you see

sp.speaker: Wig.
sp.l: Was bought by me,
You lie! you lie! you lie!
Behold this wig,
For you's too big —

sp.speaker: Shaver.
sp.l: Oh fie! oh fie! oh fie!

sp.speaker: O. and Y.
sp.l: Come yield to me,
sp.speaker: Wig.
sp.l: That shall not be,
Then, zounds, let's both resign;
I'll ne'er agree,
Without a fee —

sp.speaker: Shaver.
sp.l: The wig, kind sirs, is mine.

sp.speaker: SHAVER,
sp.stage: solus, with tye wig on his hand.
sp.l: What a shocking convulsion of late,
This old wig has produc'd in the state;
The heads can't agree,
For which it shou'd be,
Both grumble and groul in despair,
Each swears t'others claim is unfair.
Tho' now they have left it to me,
They swear that they will not agree:
What can a man do
With such a sad crew?
I will not decide on it's fate,
But try all the heads in the state.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: A Room in Mynheer Van Braken Peace's House.
Mynheer Van Braken Peace lying on a couch, a pair of very large spectacles (that are smoaked) on his nose.

sp.speaker: MEANWELL.
sp.p: My friend, Mynheer, what makes you so sad?

sp.speaker: MYNHEER.
sp.p: Mine sight! mine sight! mine sight! Oh, mine friend! the Grand Monarch be very good, he send me spectacles to see clear.

sp.speaker: MEANWELL.
sp.p:
What's the matter with your sight? your ancestors saw clear without French spectacles — they lived to a good old age,
and scorned the assistance of a French occulist — take the advice of a friend, throw off your Gallic assistants, and I'll answer for your seeing as well as ever.

sp.speaker: MYNHEER.
sp.p: Vat! drow off mine French doctor? no! no! mine French doctor know mine constitution — he be too good to let me find mine way in the dark.

sp.speaker: MEANWELL.
sp.p: I am heartily sorry to find you trust yourself to a quack — I attended you out of pure regard for your health, but, since you give no attention to my advice, I take my leave. Farewell!

sp.speaker: MYNHEER.
sp.p: Oh, mine sight! mine sight! where be mine good French doctor?

sp.speaker: DECEPTION.
sp.p: Mon cher friend! me see you have follow mon advice — You be soon see your way from home.

sp.speaker: MYNHEER.
sp.p: Oh, mine friend! me be vary glad to hear you be come to me; mine sight be vary weak.

sp.speaker: DECEPTION.
sp.p:
An verite! so much de better — Vous et in very good way of seeing right — me vill cure you quite — me have brought cet un band for your eyes.
( takes a black band out of his pocket .)
— Apropo! vous prenez cet un band pour one year — Vot constitution vill be settle for your life — me vill be your friend to lead you.

div.stage: The Doctor takes off the spectacles and puts on the bandage.

sp.speaker: MYNHEER.
sp.stage: Gets up and takes hold of the Frenchman's arm.
sp.p: Dank you, mine good friend.

sp.speaker: DECEPTION.
sp.p: Me vill give you de French air, and teach to dance a-la-mode de Paris. You no more see the Englois, and me vill cure you quite — me vill see for you.

sp.speaker: MYNHEER.
sp.p: Vat shall I do vor mine house?

sp.speaker: DECEPTION.
sp.p: Nefer mind your house — me vill mind it for you. — Alon, mon cher ami, dance avec moi.

sp.speaker: MYNHEER.
sp.p: Me can no see to dance.

sp.speaker: DECEPTION.
sp.p: Alon! alon! me vill lead you von dance.

sp.speaker: DECEPTION.
sp.p: Me have done for Mynheer, me vill blind him quite, and me vill see for him.
sp.l: Von't the varld be much surprize,
Dat me cure von Dutchman's eyes?
Me pursuade him he be blind,
Monsieur Dutchman now vill find
Dat he got no eyes to see,
He has left his eyes vit me.
Let him stumble,
Let him grumble,
Let him in von passion fly;
The more he grumble,
More he'll stumble,
Me have now put out both eye!

div.head: SCENE VI.
div.stage: Shaver's Shop, without Wigs or Blocks.
Enter SHAVER, singing Tol de rol. Enter his Man JOHN.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Oh, master, master! how can you be so merry in such sad times?

sp.speaker: SHAVER.
sp.p: What's the matter, John ? What's the matter?

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Matter enough, I think — They are going to let a tax on blockheads; but, master, what's become of yours?

sp.speaker: SHAVER.
sp.p: Go to Holland, there you'll find 'em. — A fig for the tax, my shop is clear'd of blockheads — Mynheer Van Braken Peace has purchased all my stock. — My wigs are gone to shift for themselves, and I am turn'd Contractor.

sp.speaker: SHAVER and JOHN.
sp.l: You know for who
This trade will do,
Of blockeads there are store;
The blocks just sold,
Were bad and old,
Gone to return no more.
The wigs must shift,
They're turn'd adrift,
Of numbers many score;
'Tis very true,
The numbers grew,
But now they'll grow no more.

sp.speaker: SHAVER
sp.p: I have dispos'd of all my stock of wigs except old caxen; he sticks to my head like a leech, though it has not a crooked hair in't. — Time has done it's worst there — an old wig defies all their keen touches. — The buckle is gone, and caxen would, but for me, have been thrown aside, consigned to the unwholsome occupation of a shoe-black's basket — but that ne'er shall be whilst I have a head to bear it. — As for the rest of the wigs, if they want heads, they must shift.

div.head: SCENE VII.
div.stage: A Presence Chamber in a Palace.
Americana seated in a chair of state, with suitable attendants. Trumpets sound from without, and shrieks.

sp.speaker: AMERICANA.
sp.p: What means this warlike sound, and dreadful shrieks? Has civil war broke forth and ripen'd to rebellion?

sp.speaker: LIBERTA.
sp.p: The foul deed is done! Your sons expiring call for liberty and help. — The silver brook that bore a purling stream, and panted for encrease, is now become a rapid torrent, flowing with the blood of poor departed souls! — Freedom is lost, and liberty's no more.

sp.speaker: AMERICANA.
sp.p:
Forbid it heaven! but if the baneful deed is o'er, Americana feels the power of sad distress,
(pauses)
— Pity doth stretch forth her hands, and calls to administer relief. — I come! I come! — The precious moment of redress, big with the fate of mighty empires, shall not be delay'd. — Warriors, arouse — bring forth your bows, your quivers fill — let pointed arrows prove your wonted skill! — Prepare with speed to take the field — beat the drums — let trumpets sound — for war prepare.

div.head: SCENE VIII.
div.stage: Her train supported by blacks, attendant warriors of copper colour, with bows and arrows, preceded by trumpets, drums, &.mp;c. playing martial music A flag carried before, the inscription LIBERTY.

sp.speaker: AMERICANA.
sp.p: My faithful warriors! the time is come when all your skill shall brave the insulting foe — Valor puts forth his hand, and points at Freedom — The chaste goddess calls you to her aid, and shews you realms of liberty in view. — Lead on! lead on! — Who'd not be foremost in the cause? — Draw, archers! draw your bows! — Success shall crown, though 'gainst unequal foes.

div.head: SCENE IX.
div.stage: A Street, a Poulterer's Shop in view.
Dressed in a gold laced coat and waistcoat, and his old wig.
Enter GANDER, a Poulterer, In his blue apron tucked up, and a long beard, from his shop.

sp.speaker: GANDER.
sp.p: What, my old friend, Shaver !

sp.speaker: SHAVER.
sp.p: Shaver ! — I'm a Knight! — Sir John Shaver , at your service.

sp.speaker: GANDER,
sp.p: Sir Shaver ! what masquerade are you going to? How the devil am I to get shav'd, and my wig powder'd for Sunday?

sp.speaker: SHAVER.
sp.p: If you wear your beard till I shave it, you may challenge the Grand Turk for whiskers.

sp.speaker: GANDER.
sp.p: Indeed! Sir Shaver ! How comes it that you got into such good fortune?

sp.speaker: SHAVER.
sp.p:
I turn'd contractor — dealt in a profitable commodity — charg'd enough — cheated not a little — and now I am come to what you see,
(looks at his laced coat.)
I thriv'd till I turn'd parliament man; but the devil take the luck, I must either be turn'd out of doors, or give up my contract.

sp.speaker: GANDER.
sp.p: Aye! aye! I fancy you had best put off your masquerade, for your own good and the sake of your customers.

sp.speaker: SHAVER.
sp.l: You wou'd not suppose,
That I, with these cloaths,
Cou'd e'er think of shaving again;
Or lay hold of the nose,
Both of friends and of foes,
And the feuds of the nation explain.
Now they've dubb'd me a Knight,
You'd not think it right,
That I shou'd deal open and plain;
No! shake hands with my foes,
Take my friends by the nose,
I long to be shaving again.

sp.speaker: SHAVER.
sp.p:
Gander , you have a devilish long beard, let me shave you,
(takes a case of razors out of his pocket.)
I have no objection to shaving a friend.

sp.speaker: GANDER.
sp.p: Odd so! I shou'd never recover my senses again was I shav'd by a Knight in a lac'd coat — I thank you Knight, but I must go mind my customers. — Farewell!

sp.speaker: SHAVER.
sp.stage: Cries, and takes up the flap of his coat to wipe his eyes.
sp.p: Farewell, Gander !
Gander is gone! — My friends won't keep me company — I'm left to wander about like an exil'd monarch without subjects.
sp.l: When a man success is meeting,
He can scarcely then believe,
That good fortune is not cheating,
Like punks tip you on the sleeve.
What tho' her smiles inviting prove,
Little can you hope for joy;
You may be inclin'd to love,
That love your happiness destroy.
I have ponder'd well the case,
Tho' the case seems full of doubt;
I'll seek for another place,
Since Contractors are turn'd out.

div.stage: Exit in the last strain of the air.

div.head: SCENE X.
div.stage: Enter DUTCHMAN, Blindfold, groping his way.
Enter ENGLISH SAILOR, With a coil of rope in his hand.

sp.speaker: SAILOR.
sp.p: Hollo, Mynheer! where are you bound to?

sp.speaker: MYNHEER.
sp.p: Vor Brest, to consult with mine physician, dat promise make me see long.

sp.speaker: SAILOR.
sp.stage: Gives the end of the rope to the Dutchman.
sp.p:
Damn the French pilot — You've lost sight of Ceylon, and taken your departure from the Cape of Good Hope. — Your steerage is gone — you beat about like a skiff in a squall. — Lay hold of this
hawfer — I'll take ye in tow, and moor you safe in port.
sp.l: No more, Mynheer, pine at your fate,
We'll both again be friends;
But for Monsieur he has my hate,
He fail'd to gain his ends.
Mynheer, French arts had made you blind,
When first you join'd the Gaul;
He's found to's cost 'tis an ill wind
That blows no good at all.
No more, Mynheer, pine at your fate,
We'll both again be friends;
But for Monsieur he has my hate,
He fail'd to gain his ends.

div.head: SCENE XI.
div.stage: Where the Congress are sitting at the Council Board.

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT.
sp.p: All is in the wrong. — The Gaul has fix'd his eye on the provinces of Maryland and Virginia — he has already got a footing there — we shall find him too obstinate to relinquish his claim; but the blame is not mine.

sp.speaker: SECOND MEMBER.
sp.p: Nor mine.

sp.speaker: THIRD MEMBER.
sp.p: Nor mine.

sp.speaker: FOURTH MEMBER.
sp.p:
It is too late to shift the blame. — A Frenchman is like a maggot in a nut —
put him in the middle, he'll work his way through, and leave you nothing but the shell to whistle to.

sp.speaker: FIFTH MEMBER.
sp.p: We shall lose shell and kernel too, if we trust much longer to French faith — I declare for Britain, and an expulsion of the French — I

sp.speaker: [CONGRESS]
sp.stage: A general confusion, and cry of Traitor!
sp.p: Traitor! Traitor! Hear him! Hear him! Hear him!

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT.
sp.l: Stop your bawling,
And this squalling,
It ne'er will do us good;
Each did his best,
The cash we prest,
And did whate'er we wou'd:
My friends have done,
With this sad fun,
Nor matter who is right;
Be rul'd by me,
We'll all agree,
'Tis better bawl than fight.

div.stage: PRODIGIATOR, Enter Invisible to the Congress ; he waves his wand, they gape and yawn, and fall asleep.

sp.speaker: PRODIGIATOR.
sp.stage: [Fiends appear, some dance, whilst others metamorphise the Congress with long tails tied to their hair behind, and cocked hats, with fleur de lis as cockades.
sp.l: Fiends now appear,
Discord is here,
Employ your wonted skill;
Put off the veil,
Give each a tail,
My magic pow'rs fulfill,
Grave looks no more,
The Congress o'er,
Behold the Prot'ous face;
From freedom broke,
To Gallic yoke,
They're conscious of disgrace.

div.stage: [PRODIGIATOR waves his wand and the Congress awake.

sp.speaker: CONGRESS,
sp.l: What's the members all fled,
Or have got a new head?
The de'il has sure been here;
He has alter'd each face,
And supply'd a new grace,
And made each a Monsieur.

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT.
sp.l: Our friend and ally
Was cursedly sly,
By all his fair promises led;
But since that's the case,
This room's in disgrace,
Our body ill suits with our head.

div.head: SCENE the Last.
div.stage: Enter AMERICANA and Attendants, in chains.

sp.speaker: AMERICANA
sp.p:
Perfidy assum'd the face of friendship — the Gaul profess'd he lov'd, and I belive'd. — Oh! cursed hour that first betray'd my heart — the fatal chains were then in embiyo, but now, alas! they're forg'd. — Behold these Gaulic fetters,
(pauses.)
— The sad tear, impal'd in overwhelming grief, has stopp'd it's course, and I'm denied relief.

sp.speaker: AMERICANA
sp.stage: AIR by , and CHORUS by her Followers.
sp.l: Gallic flav'ry hence! no more!
Flee again to Gallic shore;
Gallic sons may bear the chain,
I'll to Albion haste again.
Gallic sons may bear the chain,
We'll to Albion haste again.
Freedom, child of Albion's isle,
Haste, my sorrows to beguile;
Gallic tyrants rule no more
On Americana's shore.
Gallic tyrants rule no more;
Freedom dwell upon our shore.
Dear Albion come, my love to prove,
These galling fetters (proofs of love)
From Gallic faith these friends I find,
They bind these hands, but not my mind;
Dear Freedom come and ease my care,
In Albion's isle doth dwell the fair.
Bless'd Albion's name, for aye rever'd,
By'thee Americana's chear'd,
With parent fondess ease my woes,
Assist to crush our mutual foes;
For thee I sigh, for thee complain,
Haste and destroy this Gallic chain.

back.p:
FINIS.
The Author to the Door-Keeper of the Theatre. When Fancy's on the wing, and takes her flight, She'll steal your picture, whether wrong or right. You're now appriz'd, nor think my muse to blame, She shews each feature, yet conceals your name. The picture's striking, who can fail to guess The awkward portrait in a lively dress. The features fit, tho' hundreds may oppose, And swear 'tis not your head, or eyes, or nose. Your chief supporters daub me with their wit, Yet all shall own the likeness is well hit.
So , Sir, you say the Blockheads shall not appear on your Theatre. — Strange, indeed! You have only read the title page, and yet venture to guess at the whole of the business. I give you my word not a single auditor can possibly discover a line in the features of any of my Blockheads, that conveys the most distant hint at your head. You oblige me to confess, I never entertained a thought of your being a conjuror! But you have gone a great way to impress such a conclusion on my mind, by venturing to guess at the whole of the piece from the title. You have reconsidered the business, and find it is not in your power, on account of your own productions, to exhibit the Blockheads. If the old veterans have been discharged without assigning a reason, surely I may think myself fortunate in having extorted two in support of my expulsion; but still the Blockheads shall appear, so shall the sequel, together with the pigmies and anti-pigmies. The heads are nearly ready for exhibition; the moment I can compleat them, you shall have the honor of appearing the first of the groupe, if you will condescend to stand still whilst I draw your picture; if not, I'll take it flying. But should you be at a loss to distinguish one Blockhead from another, the Editor may assist you with a hint or two for your instruction. You cannot be at a loss for the definition of a Blockhead; but, to assist your memory — he has no brains, no argument can penetrate beyond the surface — The surface is a mere block that surely will never be own'd, though the likeness may provoke risibility in the by-standers. For the present I drop the curtain, that the next scene may appear with more lusture, in which I have the pleasure to assure you, no pains shall be spared to give a striking likeness; and I am, Your most devoted servant, The AUTHOR. Middle Row, New York.
